newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS - DEC 17.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS - DEC 17.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek financial press:
KATHIMERINI

--The economic burden of the continuing farmers' blockades will continue to be felt for months, the government says, with business organisations estimating losses in the region of 170 billion drachmas; the state is estimated to have already lost over 30 billion drachmas in customs tariffs and VAT. The blockades has also meant that the state will not cut interest rates on state titles further this year, a loss of 15 billion drachmas as well as another 15 billion expected to be paid as a corrective to pensions for this year.

--The OECD has called the government's economic targets for next year difficult particularly in regard to deficits. There is a possibility of further corrective measures, the OECD report - to be released Thursday - says.

--The auxiliary fund will cease to pay compensation this week and resume on January 15, sources say. At the moment, the fund has just enough to pay wages and Christmas bonuses and operating expenses for this month.
--Auditors will have their report on the Athens bourse ready by the end of the year. The main conclusions speak of speculation, titles lending and preferential treatment of certain clients.
IMERISIA
--The objective price system for real estate is to be extended to the entire country as of January 1, Deputy Finance Minister George Drys announced yesterday.
--The agreement for the first 45 billion tranche of a 265 billion drachma loan for the major regional Elefsina-Spata highway was signed yesterday with the European Investment Bank.
KERDOS

--Public servants have called a 24-hour strike today, signalling a new wave of labour unrest in light of the budget discussion in Parliament. Seamen and port workers yesterday called a 48-hour strike adding insult to the injury caused by the farmers' blockades of road and rail links.

--Hardline farmers in Thessaly have decided to bolster road blocks and march on Athens on Thursday. The government said yesterday it would stand firm on its decision not to give in to farmers' demands. Prime Minister Costas Simitis last night reiterated his call for dialogue, but on condition that the blocks are dismantled.

--The finance ministry's last issue for the year and the last tax-free issue will involve the auction of seven-year variable interest rate bonds worth 200 billion drachmas and three-year fixed-interest bonds worth 100 billion drachmas. The issue is dated December 27.
EXPRESS

--Dissension has begun to appear on barricades. The de-escalation of the crisis is near, sources say. In Brussels, EU Farm Commissioner Franz Fischler said he would examine Greece's request for immediate compensation of farmers affected by bad weather.
--The General Confederation of Workers of Greece (GSEE) and the civil servants union, ADEDY, are asking for a more just distribution of the economic burden, in their labour action today.
--The first issue of the new year, and the first taxable state titles, will be held on January 2, when the state issues Treasury bills.
--Co-founder of the 'Express'financial daily and veteran financial reporter Spyros Galaios died yesterday. Galaios's funeral will be held today at the Athens First Cemetery.
NAFTEMBORIKI

--International Monetary Fund representatives are currently being briefed on the Greek economy in order to draft their annual report. First reports say that there were reservations regarding the forecast inflation and deficit targets in the budget, following a meeting at the national economy ministry.
--Three firms will spend 107 million dollars over the next 4-6 years on exploratory drilling in western Greece.
-- Greek firms in Bulgaria invested 40.5 million dollars in 1996. --Maria Petrakis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
